content:
The simple approach is to just copy the entire setup.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer, started once and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there to replace the existing thunderbird profile there. This will prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it 
#   start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

What version of Thunderbird are you trying to install, and on what version of Windows 10? I'm running version 140.5.0esr on Windows 10 Pro 22H2 64-bit. I see that the latest Thunderbird, 145.0 should also run on Windows 10.

Maybe you have a corrupted install file? Try downloading it again. Both the monthly release (145) and the latest Extended Support Release (most stable) are available at:

https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/

Best to reboot before installing.

content:
Hi Aidan.

Blocking is not possible in Thunderbird. You may be able to do it at the server.

What you can do is Thunderbird, as you seem to know, is filter messages to trash, junk, or somewhere else. To start creating a message filter, use Tools (menu) > Message Filters.

You can access the same function through the three horizontal lines on the toolbar.
creator: mozilla98

content:
Select a message, then Message/Create Filter From Message... Press Alt if the Menu Bar with Message is hidden.

But it's better to block (or whitelist) senders through the options offered in the webmail settings for the account - which are applied even when TB is closed or before mail is downloaded.

content:
Možná příčina je v tom, že Thunderbird je spuštěný jako správce (admin). Podle několika uživatelů přetahování (drag & drop) příloh nefunguje, jestliže Thunderbird běží „jako administrátor“.

Zkus: klikni pravým tlačítkem na zástupce Thunderbird → Vlastnosti → Kompatibilita → odškrtnout „Spustit jako administrátor“. Poté znovu spusť Thunderbird a vyzkoušej táhnout soubor.
creator: Ansamb

content:
1: Yes.

2: No, you will use the same accounts as before, as you mentioned in #1.

3. Depends on what you mean by “empower” and “control” and what you want to accomplish. People who know Thunderbird can set up gmail and iCloud accounts in a few minutes. Thunderbird can do very much. Some complexity comes with power. There are several very knowledgeable people on this forum who can help you with specific issues. For example, iCloud requires an app-specific password that you must create at Apple. gmail may also. I do not know. Other people here know gmail and Thunderbird well.
creator: mozilla98

content:
Try this:

  1. click help>troubleshootinginformation on windows pc
  2. scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  3. exit thunderbird - IMPORTANT
  4. you are now in the profile folder. copy ALL of it and save to external media
  5. install thunderbird on linux, if not already done
  6. click help>troubleshootinginformation
  7. scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  8. exit thunderbird
  9. you are in the profile. Paste what you copied here ########
  10. restart thunderbird

CAVEAT: from various linux posts, i think the profile is not consistent to thunderbird default, so you may need to check that.

content:
The message that you shared does not provide evidence of that kind of problem. Would you please post screenshots of error messages that mention SPF and DKIM issues?

What do you mean by a "Firefox account"? Do you mean your popbox account? Firefox is not relevant here, and there is no Thunderbird account.

SPF and DKIM authenticate the sender, so problems with them do indeed indicate a problem with the sender. Would you please post a screenshot of your SMTP settings? You can find them in Account settings > click on account name > "edit outgoing server..."
creator: mozilla98

content:
Is Thunderbird set up to access your email via IMAP or POP3? If you follow the TalkTalk guy's suggestion to delete and recreate the account in Thunderbird, and you use POP3, you may, indeed lose some email because the only copies of the mail might exist only on your computer. If you use IMAP, the email should be safe, because it it storied both on the mail server and on your computer.

But the first thing to do would be to confirm your email settings in Thunderbird. Can you tell us what its incoming and outgoing settings are? Look under <Account Settings | Server Settings> and <Account Settings | Outgoing Server (SMTP) </p>

Here are TalkTalk's recommended settings, according to their web site:

Incoming Mail Settings

Incoming mail server: mail.talktalk.net Security Type (for Android): SSL/TLS or SSL Encryption Method (for Windows/Mac Mail): SSL/TLS Server Port (all devices if using IMAP): 993 Server Port (all devices if using POP3): 995

Outgoing Mail Settings

Outgoing mail server: smtp.talktalk.net Security Type (for Android): STARTTLS or TLS Encryption Method (for Windows): STARTTLS Server Port (all devices): 587
creator: rednoise

content:
Can I assume you have rebooted? That can often fix such anomalies. Otherwise...

I'll guess that it's your anti-virus that's interfering with file writing. As a test, try temporarily disabling your AV (MS Defender?) to see if that helps. Be careful, though - it may have flagged a questionable email, triggering the "write" error.
creator: rednoise

content:

I don't know why my anti-virus software would suddenly cause a problem - I use AVG and it's worked happily alongside TB for many years. AVG is very good at flagging potential problems. But I will carefully examine the emails that arrived around the time of the problem.

So the situation is: TB will download emails but can't write them to the profile file so they don't appear in the Inbox. I can send email perfectly well.

creator: siffemoz

content:
Dit is een fout die in uw mailbox is geslopen. Ik vond dit artikel met daarin hoe het probleem kan worden opgelost:

  1. Open eerst de Thunderbird-toepassing en ga naar Accountinstellingen.
  2. Klik op de map Lokaal en kopieer het gewenste pad voor een lokale map of sla het op.
  3. Sluit de Thunderbird-toepassing zorgvuldig en volledig af.
  4. Kopieer het pad en plak het in de gewenste locatie waar uw Thunderbird-gegevens zijn opgeslagen.
  5. Zoek vervolgens naar het bestand inbox.msf en verwijder het permanent.
  6. Start nu de Thunderbird-toepassing. Deze zal het verwijderde bestand (inbox.msf) opnieuw opbouwen.

In het artikel staan ook nog een paar andere oplossingsmogelijkheden, zoals Thunderbird opnieuw installeren of upgraden. We horen graag of het probleem hiermee is opgelost!
creator: markh2

content:
Try turning off hardware acceleration.

For TB:

- go to TB Menu > Settings and enter 'hardware' (no quotes) in the search box 

  - uncheck 'Use hardware acceleration when available'

- close the tab and restart TB

For FF:

Try turning off hardware acceleration:

Go to FF Menu > Settings and enter 'hardware' (no quotes) in the search box

- uncheck 'Use recommended performance settings'

- uncheck 'Use hardware acceleration when available'

- close the tab and restart FF
creator: siffemoz

content: Please post your Troubleshooting Information. At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button ≡, then select Help > Troubleshooting Information. Press the "Copy text to clipboard button" and paste the information into your reply.
